{{Unreferenced|date=June 2008}}
The '''Doctor of Information Technology''' (DIT) is a research-oriented [[Doctorate#Professional doctorates|professional doctoral degree]] offered by some universities. It is of the same academic level as traditional PhD; however, DIT research focuses more on industry practice than on theoretical framework. Upon successful completion, the title of "Doctor" is awarded and the post-nominals of DIT can be used.
Charles Sturt University description
The Doctor of Information Technology offers the research opportunity to extend knowledge of the discipline of information and communication technology and develops the attributes required to successfully identify, investigate and resolve problems and opportunities in today's IT industry [http://www.csu.edu.au/courses/postgraduate/information_technology_doctor/course-overview].
Towson's University description
Towson University's Doctor of Science (D.Sc.) program in information technology constitutes a broad scope of research areas including: Computer Science (CS), Information Systems (IS) and Information Technology (IT). This program prepares students to become professors, scientists, and entrepreneurs. Graduates assume leadership roles in their current careers or in academic, research, government and state of the art industry positions. About half of our alumni are currently working as tenure-track assistant professors or research scientists across the country and abroad in CS, IS, and IT fields. After graduation, some alumni remained with their current employers and were promoted to higher level positions. Others started their own ventures to develop innovative products [http://grad.towson.edu/program/doctoral/ait-scd/].
University of Northern Virginia Description
The Doctor of Information Technology (DIT) addresses the expanding needs of professionals who manage information resources; solve information, communication and technology-related problems in businesses and other organizations; or educate and/or train others in fields related to the applications of information systems and communications. This is an intensive program designed primarily to develop practitioners and teaching faculty with very high levels of both technical and analytical expertise in specific fields of information technology (IT). Admission to the program is competitive. Meeting a specific set of minimum qualification does not assure admission [https://web.archive.org/web/20130806041507/http://unva.edu/doctor-information-technology.html].
==Schools Offering DIT Degrees==
Australia * {{flagicon|Australia}} [[Charles Sturt University]] [http://www.csu.edu.au/courses/postgraduate/information_technology_doctor/] * {{flagicon|Australia}} [[Edith Cowan University]] [https://archive.is/20081120073952/http://www.scis.ecu.edu.au/Future/Courses/Postgraduate/215/Doctor+of+Information+Technology] * {{flagicon|Australia}} [[Monash University]] [http://www.mrgs.monash.edu.au/scholarships/guide/programs.html] * {{flagicon|Australia}} [[Murdoch University]] [https://web.archive.org/web/20080801212114/http://handbook.murdoch.edu.au/courses/detail.lasso?us=ITD&year=2008] * {{flagicon|Australia}} [[Queensland University of Technology]] [http://www.courses.qut.edu.au/cgi-bin/WebObjects/Courses.woa/wa/selectMajorFromMain?courseID=6592] * {{flagicon|Australia}} [[University of Ballarat]] [https://web.archive.org/web/20080726044816/http://web.ballarat.edu.au/ard/itms/courses/hd_research.shtml] * {{flagicon|Australia}} [[University of New South Wales]] [http://www.itee.adfa.edu.au/prospective/dit.html] * {{flagicon|Australia}} [[University of South Australia]] [https://archive.is/20121127023159/http://www.unisanet.unisa.edu.au/programs/program.asp?Program=LPIN]
Canada * {{flagicon|Canada}} [[University of Toronto]] [http://www.ischool.utoronto.ca/phd]
Namibia * {{flagicon|Namibia}} [[University of Namibia]] [http://www.unam.na]
Philippines * {{flagicon|Philippines}} AMA Computer University * {{flagicon|Philippines}} Cebu Institute of Technology - University * {{flagicon|Philippines}} St. Paul University - Tuguegarao * {{flagicon|Philippines}} Dela Salle University * {{flagicon|Philippines}} St. Linus University * {{flagicon|Philippines}} Technological Institute of the Philippines * {{flagicon|Philippines}} Angeles University Foundation * {{flagicon|Philippines}} University of the Cordilleras * {{flagicon|Philippines}} [https://www.ue.edu.ph/manila/main.html?page=colleges&link=gs_requirements University of the East - Manila]
United States *{{flagicon|United States}} [[Walden University]] [https://www.waldenu.edu/doctoral/doctor-of-information-technology] *{{flagicon|United States}} Capella University *{{flagicon|United States}} University of Texas, San Antonio *{{flagicon|United States}} George Mason University *{{flagicon|United States}} MIT *{{flagicon|United States}} [[Stratford University]] [http://www.stratford.edu/computer-information-systems/doctor-of-information-technology] *{{flagicon|United States}} Atlantic International University
Mexico * {{flagicon|Mexico}} University of Guadalajara * {{flagicon|Mexico}} Popular Autonomous University of Puebla
{{Academic degrees}}
[[Category:Doctoral degrees|Information Technology, Doctor of]] [[Category:Information technology qualifications]]

{{For|the Boogie Down Productions album|Edutainment (album)}} {{See also|Entertainment in education|Social Impact Entertainment}} [[File:Development-Entertainment Continuum.png|thumb|Educational Entertainment on [[Venn diagram]]]]
'''Educational entertainment''' (also referred to by the [[portmanteau]] [[neologism]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://whatis.techtarget.com/definition/edutainment |title=Definition of "Edutainment" |access-date=2015-02-14 |dead-url=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150214122205/http://whatis.techtarget.com/definition/edutainment |archive-date=2015-02-14 |df=}}</ref> '''edutainment'''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/edutainment |title=edutainment |publisher=[[Merriam-Webster]] |access-date=2012-10-16 |dead-url=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121113084132/http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/edutainment |archive-date=2012-11-13 |df=}}</ref>) is media designed to [[education|educate]] through [[entertainment]]. Most often it includes content intended to teach but has incidental entertainment value. It has been used by academia, corporations, governments, and other entities in various countries to disseminate information in classrooms and/or via television, radio, and other media to influence viewers' opinions and behaviors.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Rapeepisarn |first1=K. |last2=Wong |first2=K. W. |last3=Fung |first3=C. C. |last4=Depickere |first4=A. |year=2006 |publisher=[[Murdoch University]] |location=[[Perth]] |url=http://researchrepository.murdoch.edu.au/id/eprint/993/1/Published_Version.pdf |title=Similarities and differences between "learn through play" and "edutainment" |pages=28–32 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170817204405/http://researchrepository.murdoch.edu.au/id/eprint/993/1/Published_Version.pdf |archive-date=2017-08-17}} In: Proceedings of the 3rd Australasian Conference on Interactive Entertainment, 4–6 December 2006.</ref>
== History ==
=== Concept === Interest in combining education with entertainment, especially in order to make learning more enjoyable, has existed for hundreds of years, with the [[Renaissance]] and [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] being movements in which this combination was presented to students.<ref name=":0">{{Cite conference|title=Edutainment or Education: Education Possibilities of Didactic Games in Science Education|format=pdf|date=September 2007|location=Brno, Czech Republic|url=http://www.iccp-play.org/documents/brno/nemec_trna.pdf|access-date=12 April 2017|editor=Němec, J.|pages=55–64|conference=ICCP Brno Conference|last1=Trna|first1=Josef|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170817210858/http://www.iccp-play.org/documents/brno/nemec_trna.pdf|archivedate=17 August 2017|df=}}</ref> [[John Amos Comenius|Komenský]] in particular is affiliated with the “school as play” concept, which proposes [[pedagogy]] with dramatic or delightful elements.<ref name=":0" /> [[File:Poor Richard Almanack 1739.jpg|link=[[:File:Poor Richard Almanack 1739]].jpg|left|thumb|213x213px|''[[Poor Richard's Almanack]]'']] [[Poor Richard's Almanack|''Poor Richard’s Almanack'']] demonstrates early implementation of edutainment, with [[Benjamin Franklin]] combining entertaining and educational content, such as puzzles and rules of conduct, into an instructional entity for colonists.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/20/education/turning-to-education-for-fun.html|title=Turning to Education for Fun|last=Beato|first=Greg|date=2015-03-19|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-04-12|issn=0362-4331|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170105130008/http://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/20/education/turning-to-education-for-fun.html|archivedate=2017-01-05|df=}}</ref>
Later development of the concept of edutainment can be tied to [[Walt Disney]], with his first educational short film, [[Tommy Tucker's Tooth|''Tommy Tucker’s Tooth'']], being commissioned and shot in 1922 for the Deneer Dental Institute.<ref>Miller, Diane Disney (1957). ''The Story of Walt Disney''. NY: Henry Holt and Co. p. 79. {{ISBN|978-0-7868-5562-9}}. As cited in Shale, Richard (1982). ''Donald Duck Joins Up: The Walt Disney Studio During World War II''. Ann Arbor, Michigan: UMI Research Press. p. 15.{{ISBN|9780835713108}}.</ref> The entry of the [[United States|U.S.]] into [[World War II]] also had a major impact on the popularity of educational entertainment, as a relationship between Disney and the U.S. government formed; Disney was able to experiment with educational and nonfiction films in a way that continued even after the war,<ref name=":11">{{Cite book|title=Donald Duck Joins Up: The Walt Disney Studio During World War II|last=Shale|first=Richard|publisher=UMI Research Press|year=1982|isbn=978-0-8357-1310-8|location=Ann Arbor, Michigan|pages=67, 109, 149}}</ref> with series such as ''[[True-Life Adventures]]''<ref>{{Cite book|title=Walt and the Promise of Progress City|last=Gennawey|first=Sam|publisher=Ayefour Publishing|year=2011|isbn=978-0-615-54024-5|location=|pages=29}}</ref> and [[Walt Disney's Disneyland|''Disneyland'']].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Newell|first=Catherine L.|title=The Strange Case of Dr. von Braun and Mr. Disney: Frontierland, Tomorrowland, and America’s Final Frontier|journal=The Journal of Religion and Popular Culture|language=en|volume=25|issue=3|pages=416–429|doi=10.3138/jrpc.25.3.416|year=2013}}</ref> In the transcript of an interview with [[Alexander P. de Seversky]] from The Walt Disney Archives, of which its date and interviewer is unknown,<ref name=":11" /> the following quotation is found:{{Quote|text=It is a new kind of entertainment that goes far beyond simply "amusing" its audience. This picture is vital entertainment--it treats on a subject that directly affects every man, woman, and child, in America. With dramatic action it exposes the basic ideas that will rid the mind of confusion and clarify the war thinking of the public.|sign=Walt Disney|source=Interview with Alexander de Seversky}}Since the 1970s, various groups in the United States, the United Kingdom, and Latin America have used edutainment to address health and social issues such as [[substance abuse]], [[immunization]], [[teenage pregnancy]], [[HIV]]/[[AIDS]], and [[cancer]]. Initiatives in major universities, such as [[Johns Hopkins University]]<ref name=":12">{{Cite book|title=Entertainment-Education and Social Change: History, Research, and Practice|last=Singhal|first=Arvind|last2=Michael J.|first2=Cody|last3=Rogers|first3=Everett M.|last4=Sabido|first4=Miguel|publisher=Routledge|year=2003|isbn=978-1-135-62456-9|location=|pages=7, 39}}</ref> and the [[University of Wisconsin-Madison]], [[NGOs]] such as PCI-Media Impact, and government agencies such as the U.S. [[Centers for Disease Control]] (CDC)<ref name=":12" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/healthcommunication/toolstemplates/entertainmented/|title=Entertainment Education {{!}} Gateway to Health Communication {{!}} CDC|website=www.cdc.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2017-04-12|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170120135351/https://www.cdc.gov/healthcommunication/ToolsTemplates/EntertainmentEd/|archivedate=2017-01-20|df=}}</ref> have produced edutainment content.
Modern forms of edutainment include television productions, film, museum exhibits, and computer software which use entertainment to attract and maintain an audience, while incorporating deliberate educational content or messages. It is also apparent that educational elements are becoming implemented into traditionally recreational realms, such as vacations and games.<ref name=":1" />
=== Terminology === The term edutainment was used as early as 1954 by [[Walt Disney]] to describe the ''[[True Life Adventures]]'' series.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=DISNEY|first=WALT|date=1954-01-01|title=EDUCATIONAL VALUES IN FACTUAL NATURE PICTURES|jstor=42922993|journal=Educational Horizons|volume=33|issue=2|pages=82–84}}</ref> The [[noun]] ''edutainment'' is a [[Neologism|neologistic]] [[portmanteau]] used by Robert Heyman in 1973 while producing documentaries for the [[National Geographic Society]].<ref>Marta Rey-López et al. A Model for Personalized Learning. In: Adaptive Hypermedia and Adaptive Web-Based Systems. Springer. Berlin. 2006.</ref> It was also used by Dr. Chris Daniels in 1975 to encapsulate the theme of his Millennium Project. This project later became known as The Elysian World Project.<ref name="elysianworld2">{{cite web|url=http://www.elysianworld.com|title=Elysian World|publisher=elysianworld.com|accessdate=November 6, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141217052758/http://elysianworld.com/|archivedate=December 17, 2014|df=}}</ref> The offshoot word "Edutainer" has been used by Craig Sim Webb since before the turn of the millennium to describe an individual who offers edutainment presentations and performances.<ref name="edutainer2">{{cite web|url=http://www.edutainer.ca|title=Inspirational speakers – Professional Inspirational Speaker, Performer, Songwriter & Author|publisher=edutainer.ca|accessdate=November 6, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141027001013/http://edutainer.ca/|archivedate=October 27, 2014|df=}}</ref>
== Application ==
=== Audio and video === ''[[Schoolhouse Rock]]'', ''[[Wishbone (TV series)|Wishbone]]'', ''[[Sesame Street]]'', and ''[[Bill Nye the Science Guy]]'' are examples of shows that use [[music]] and video to teach topics like math, science, and history. Using music to aid memory dates back to the passing of ancient oral traditions, including the ''[[Iliad]]'' and the ''[[Odyssey]]''. Much of what edutainment can offer through audio and video especially, is accessible over the internet on platforms such as [[YouTube]], with such channels as ''[[Vsauce]]'', ''[[CGP Grey]]'', ''[[MinutePhysics]]'', ''Meet Arnold, ''[[Veritasium]]'', and ''[[Crash Course (YouTube)|Crash Course]]''.
[[Public Service Broadcasting (band)|Public Service Broadcasting]] is a band that incorporates audio and footage from the [[British Film Institute]] into their music and performances, and this partnership helps the British Film Institute showcase its material; their album ''[[Inform-Educate-Entertain|Inform—Educate—Entertain]]''[[Inform-Educate-Entertain|,]] which covers topics such as the climbing of [[Mount Everest]] and [[highway safety]], demonstrates the connection between the concept of edutainment and their music.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/archival-delights-public-service-broadcasting|title=The Archival Delights of Public Service Broadcasting|date=2015-02-24|website=The New Yorker|access-date=2017-04-13|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170422133120/http://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/archival-delights-public-service-broadcasting|archivedate=2017-04-22|df=}}</ref>
=== Film and television === {{Main|Educational television}}
Motion pictures with educational content appeared as early as 1943, such as ''[[Private Snafu]]'', and can still be seen in films such as ''[[An Inconvenient Truth]]''. After [[World War II]], educational entertainment shifted towards television. Television programs can be divided into three main categories: those with primarily educational intentions, those with a high degree of both education and entertainment, and entertainment shows with incidental or occasional educational value.
Mexican TV producer Miguel Sabido pioneered in the 1970s a form of edutainment via [[telenovelas]], "soap operas for social change". The "Sabido method" has been adopted in many other countries subsequently, including India, Peru, Kenya, and China.<ref>Hanna Rosin, "Life Lessons: How Soap Operas Can Change the World", ''The New Yorker'', June 5, 2006, pp. 40-45.</ref> In Mexico, the government in the 1970s successfully used a telenovela to promote family planning to curb the country's high birthrate.<ref>Gabriela Soto Laveaga, "'Let's become fewer': Soap operas, contraception, and nationalizing the Mexican family in an overpopulated world." ''Sexuality Research and Social Policy''. September 2007, vol. 4,, no. 3 pp. 19-33.</ref>
The third season of the television show ''MTV Shuga'' was analyzed by researchers and then published online in 2017 in terms of its effects related to its goal of educating African youth about [[Sexual Health|sexual health]] and [[HIV/AIDS in Africa|HIV]], and secondarily, [[Gender based violence|gender-based violence]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.worldbank.org/en/news/feature/2017/02/23/mtv-shuga-soap-opera-turns-edutainment-into-a-tool-to-fight-hiv-and-gender-based-violence|title=MTV Shuga Soap Opera Turns Edutainment into a Tool to Fight HIV and Gender-Based Violence|last=|first=|date=2017-02-27|work=World Bank|access-date=2017-04-20|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170422212033/http://www.worldbank.org/en/news/feature/2017/02/23/mtv-shuga-soap-opera-turns-edutainment-into-a-tool-to-fight-hiv-and-gender-based-violence|archive-date=2017-04-22|dead-url=no|language=en|df=}}</ref> In the [[Randomized controlled trial|randomized control trials]], those in the treatment group who watched the show for six months were “almost twice as likely” to get tested at HIV testing centers; mixed results were found in regards to the show’s effects on gender-based violence.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://pubdocs.worldbank.org/en/438421467236362785/Entertainment-Edu-workshop-Flyer-6-3-16.pdf|title=EXPERIMENTAL EVALUATION OF MTV SHUGA: CHANGING SOCIAL NORMS AND BEHAVIORS WITH ENTERTAINMENT EDUCATION|last=Banerjee|first=Abhijit|last2=La Ferrara|first2=Eliana|date=2017|website=World Bank|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170315174725/http://pubdocs.worldbank.org/en/438421467236362785/Entertainment-Edu-workshop-Flyer-6-3-16.pdf|archive-date=2017-03-15|dead-url=no|access-date=|last3=Orozco|first3=Victor|df=}}</ref>
According to the article [["Walt Disney: Master of Laughter and Learning"]] Walt Disney believed in education through the entertainment of film and television. He is known as the master of communications who brought both entertainment and education into the world in distinctive ways. His creation of mickey mouse and his adventures taught his audience that life is not always so simple, there will be obstacles that will stand in your way. Mickey mouse's is unpolished and imperfect which make him so realistic to his audience. In many of his stories we see him battle and adventure which he overcomes teach a value in life for viewers, keep going in life. Disney achieved and educational characteristic in his work through the picture series of live animals in their natural habitat by which some film techniques added to the drama of the series. This series was one that satisfied Walt Disney the most as it obtained both the qualities of entertainment and education, which was the characteristics of this series.<ref>{{cite journal|jstor=1491447|title=Walt Disney: Master of Laughter and Learning|first=Ralph S.|last=Izard|date=12 May 1967|publisher=|journal=Peabody Journal of Education|volume=45|issue=1|pages=36–41}}</ref>
=== Healthcare === Educating the public about health issues is a focus for many stakeholders, including the pharmaceutical industry. In recent years, several initiatives have used educational entertainment principles to highlight specific conditions or wider healthcare issues. Examples include In Memory about dementia,<ref name="HEALTHCARE FEATURE FILMS: IN MEMORY">{{cite web|title=HEALTHCARE FEATURE FILMS: IN MEMORY|url=https://bedrock-health.com/healthcare-feature-films/|website=Bedrock|accessdate=3 November 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107022823/https://bedrock-health.com/healthcare-feature-films/|archivedate=7 November 2017|df=}}</ref> Millefeuille about psoriasis<ref name="Millefeuille">{{cite web|title=Millefeuille|url=http://www.millefeuillemovie.com/|website=Millefeuille|publisher=Celgene|accessdate=3 November 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107030657/http://www.millefeuillemovie.com/|archivedate=7 November 2017|df=}}</ref> and This is Axiom about the challenges facing the UK's National Health Service.<ref name="This is Axiom">{{cite web|title=This is Axiom|url=http://thisisaxiommovie.com/|website=This is Axiom|publisher=Celgene|accessdate=3 November 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107020639/http://thisisaxiommovie.com/|archivedate=7 November 2017|df=}}</ref>
=== Games === {{Main|Educational game}}
Games fulfill a number of educational purposes. Some games may be explicitly designed with education in mind, while others may have incidental or secondary educational value. All types of games, including [[board game|board]], [[card game|card]], and video games, may be used in an educational environment. Educational games are designed to teach people about certain subjects, expand concepts, reinforce development, understand an historical event or culture, or assist them in learning a skill as they play.
According to Paraskeva (2010), at least 68% of American households play video games. Many recent research articles postulate education and gaming can be joined to provide academic benefits.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Paraskeva | first1 = F. | last2 = Mysirlaki | first2 = S. | last3 = Papgianni | first3 = A. | year = 2010 | title = Multiplayer online games as educational tools: Facing new challenges in learning | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0360131509002413 | journal = Computers and Education | volume = 54 | issue = | pages = 498–505 | doi=10.1016/j.compedu.2009.09.001}}</ref>
According to Van Eck (2006), there are three reasons why games are considered learning tools: 1. Ongoing research that has included the last 20 years of educational findings have proven that digital games can be educational; 2. The new generation of today wants "multiple streams of information" (p. 1), which includes quick and frequent interaction that allows inductive reasoning; and 3. The mere popularity of games has created a billion-dollar industry. The idea of playing a game assumes the person is engaging in that activity by choice. The activity should have some value of "fun". This does not mean that the person is engaging in the activity only for leisure pursuits; it can also include the desire to learn a skill, connect with other gamers (social community), and spend time in a chosen activity. The activity needs to remain one of choice for the gamer.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Van Eck|first=R.|year=2006|title=Digital game-based learning: It's not just the digital natives who are restless...|publisher=Educase Review|volume=41|issue=2|pages=1–16|url=http://edergbl.pbworks.com/w/file/fetch/47991237/digital%20game%20based%20learning%202006.pdf|format=PDF|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229182518/http://edergbl.pbworks.com/w/file/fetch/47991237/digital%20game%20based%20learning%202006.pdf|archivedate=2016-12-29|df=}}</ref>
Kim (2008) supports the use of off-the-shelf games with [[Metacognition|meta-cognitive]] strategies to provide an increase in students' cognitive performance.<ref>Kim, B., Park, H., & Baek, Y. (2009)</ref><ref>Computers and Education, 52, 800-810</ref>
=== Radio and podcasts ===
[[Radio]] can serve as an effective vehicle for educational entertainment. The British radio soap opera ''[[The Archers]]'' has for decades been systematically educating its audience on agricultural matters; likewise, the [[Tanzania]]n radio soap opera ''Twende na Wakati'' ("Let's Go With the Times") was written primarily to promote [[family planning]].
Likewise, [[podcast]]s have begun to exemplify the concept of edutainment, with some radio programs also becoming available in this digital format. Not only are there are series with educational elements that are listened to recreationally, but there are also [[Uses of podcasting#Education and academia|podcasts used as an educational tool]]. Lessons based on podcasts have increased in popularity, with [[Teacherspayteachers.com|''TeachersPayTeachers'']] finding that lesson plans relating to podcasts rose in downloads by 21 percent and 650 percent in 2014 and 2015, respectively, which corresponded with the release of ''[[Serial (podcast)|Serial]]''.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/education/archive/2016/03/the-benefits-of-podcasts-in-class/473925/|title=Using 'Serial' to Get Students to Read More|last=Godsey|first=Michael|work=The Atlantic|access-date=2017-04-13|language=en-US|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170209125945/https://www.theatlantic.com/education/archive/2016/03/the-benefits-of-podcasts-in-class/473925/|archivedate=2017-02-09|df=}}</ref>
Other successful radio programs and/or podcasts that have fused entertainment and education include: *[[DJ Nihal]]'s [[BBC Radio 1]] radio show which centered around 'edutainment'. He mentions this term each time the show is broadcast.{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}} *"The Lawsons/[[Blue Hills (radio serial)|Blue Hills]]" – a radio program that was designed to help Australian farmers adjust to new farming methods.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/51399122/5793294|title=Twenty years with the good folk of 'Blue Hills'|last=|first=|date=24 June 1964|work=The Australian Women's Weekly|access-date=13 April 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180512173617/https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/51399122/5793294|archive-date=2018-05-12|dead-url=no|page=5|df=}}</ref> *"Tinka Tinka Sukh" – a Hindi – language radio program that results in environmental and health improvements in India.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://mediaimpact.org/production/tinka-tinka-sukh/|title=Tinka Tinka Sukh (Little Step, Little Step to a Better Life)|date=2014-04-09|work=PCI Media Impact|access-date=2017-04-13|language=en-US|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150510094842/http://mediaimpact.org/production/tinka-tinka-sukh/|archivedate=2015-05-10|df=}}</ref> *Soul City – A successful South African radio serial drama that carried AIDS prevention messages.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.saiia.org.za/archive-eafrica/soul-city-a-strategy-for-small-screen-education|title=SAIIA – Soul City: A Strategy for Small-Screen Education|last=Wilson|first=Gretchen|website=www.saiia.org.za|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-04-13|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170808080241/http://www.saiia.org.za/archive-eafrica/soul-city-a-strategy-for-small-screen-education|archivedate=2017-08-08|df=}}</ref> *The Donut Shop – A successful internet radio show talk about educational games that they think could be used in today's schools. *Radio Ado and its radiodrama "Pildoritas de la Vida Real", a Mexican radio soap opera designed to disseminate sexual education among teenagers. This radiodrama was produced by the University of Guadalajara and teenagers from Morelia, Michoacan, Mexico. *Khirki Mehendiwali – In an endeavour to improve maternal and child health practices in Bihar, a 37 episode long Radio Show Khirki Mehendiwali was created for the rural audience by [http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediaaction/where_we_work/asia/india BBC Media Action, India]. Each approximately 15 – minute episode beautifully blends information with entertainment to disseminate one specific message on maternal and child health. The show provides a window to the world to its rural listeners by not only giving them a glimpse of the world outside but also unlocking voices, feelings, dreams and information, which they had hitherto not heard or experienced.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rethink1000days.org/programme-outputs/khirki-mehendiwali/|title=Khirki Mehendiwali {{!}} Shaping Demand and Practices {{!}} BBC Media === Toys === {{Main|Educational toy}}
Toys are perhaps the earliest "edutainment" objects a person encounters, as many toys have also an educational aspect beside their [[aesthetic]] appeal. They can teach children literacy, numerical, conceptual or motor skills. Many toys (e.g., a miniature [[piano]]) are simply colorful, scaled-down versions of more complex objects, and thus can base children in skills and benefits associated with the latter. It is up to grown-ups to guide children to the toy's proper use in order to make the most out of it.
Toys are often employed in the context of [[mimicry]] and [[roleplay]] to partially experience personalities or situations not otherwise possible, very akin to [[simulation]] in video games. They can be used as primitive means to nurture an [[instinct]] or a [[character trait]] in children. Often, toys work simultaneously the other way, providing children with the means to ''express'' those things: a doll may be used by a girl to mimic her mother or express [[motherhood]] as much as to explore it.
Even for toys that don't possess explicit educational value, a thoughtful parent or teacher can turn a static [[figurine]], for example, into an object of interest, by pointing out its features or costumes, or referring to its history or science (e.g., a figurine of a [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] may be a starting point for exploring American history; a [[Santa Claus]] may be used to explore the roots of Christmas; a toy [[astronaut]] to explore science...), which can be done in conjunction with a more-explicitly "edutaining" object, such as a [[picture book]]. Most children are naturally inquisitive (possibly why they sometimes break their toys; simply to know what is inside or how it moves or what produces that sound), and caregivers should not waste this opportunity.
Even ''grown-ups'' can learn through toys about children: what are their [[Aptitude|talents]] or interests; if they are more [[extrovert]] or [[introvert]]; indeed if they dislike toys and prefer social activities or sport, and thus capitalize on the children's abilities and correct what is wrong or lacking.
Some toys are of considerable appeal and benefit to both children and adults, such as [[Lego]] or [[Rubik's Cube]], as their design and implementation can range from the simple to the sophisticated.
=== Hip hop culture === The term "edutainment" was first made popular amongst the hip hop community by [[KRS-One]] (a.k.a. The Teacha) thanks to his [[Boogie Down Productions]] [[Edutainment (album)|album by the same name]].
The term has since been borrowed to describe hip hop culture's innate pedagogical aesthetics. Examples of this include how Hip Hop uniquely combines both thought and action (see [[Paulo Freire]]'s use of [[Praxis (process)|praxis]] in ''[[Pedagogy of the Oppressed]]'') and values both Eurocentric values of rational thought and Afrocentric epistemology of kinetic, affective and emotional ways of knowing.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Hip-Hop Culture in College Students' Lives|last=Petchauer|first=Emery|publisher=Routledge|year=2012|isbn=978-0-415-88971-1|location=New York|pages=72|quote=}}</ref> Another example is in the transmission of technical and historical knowledge, the manner in which Hip Hop practitioners learn and exchange by sharing moments of performance together through ''building'' or ''building sessions.''<ref>{{Cite book|title=Hip-Hop Culture in College Students' Lives|last=Petchauer|first=Emery|publisher=Routledge|year=2012|isbn=978-0-415-88971-1|location=New-York|pages=76–77|quote=}}</ref>
=== Corporations === The concept of educational entertainment is being used for building learning programs for organizations. High technology is used to make the programs entertaining and educational.<ref>{{Cite book|title=E-Content: Technologies and Perspectives for the European Market|last=Nagy|first=Atilla|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|year=2006|isbn=3-540-25093-X|location=|pages=79–96|chapter=The Impact of E-Learning}}</ref> As an example, [[PowerPoint]] presentations may become more entertaining with the addition of flashy animations or graphics. An article in a satirical newspaper, ''[[The Onion]]'', poked fun at the concept of embellishing boring presentations with attention-catching effects.<ref name="Onion2">{{cite web|url=http://www.theonion.com/articles/wow-factor-added-to-corporate-presentation,2766/|title=Wow Factor Added To Corporate Presentation | The Onion – America's Finest News Source|publisher=theonion.com|accessdate=November 6, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141106232425/http://www.theonion.com/articles/wow-factor-added-to-corporate-presentation,2766/|archivedate=November 6, 2014|df=}}</ref> A fictional marketing executive in the article noted the previous lack of excitement in the presentation, saying "When we first finished the PowerPoint, the content was all there, but it still lacked that certain something."<ref name="Onion2" />
=== Theme parks === {{Main|Amusement park#Educational theme parks}} [[File:Spaceship Earth at EPCOT.jpg|link=[[:File:Spaceship Earth at EPCOT]].jpg|thumb|[[Spaceship Earth (Epcot)|Spaceship Earth]], an attraction at [[Epcot]]]] Theme parks are a specific kind of setting in which the combination of entertaining and educational elements can be prevalent. [[Epcot]] at [[Walt Disney World]], which is owned by [[The Walt Disney Company]], is highly based on edutainment; the park features attractions that teach about the past, conservation, imagination, future technologies, and the world. The park's dedication plaque, written by [[Marty Sklar]] and Erwin Okun, states the following: “May [[EPCOT Center]] entertain, inform and inspire. And above all, may it instill a new sense of belief and pride in man’s ability to shape a world that offers hope to people everywhere."<ref>{{Cite book|title=Dream It! Do It!: My Half-Century Creating Disney's Magic Kingdoms|last=Sklar|first=Marty|publisher=Disney Editions|year=2013|isbn=978-1-4231-7406-6|location=|pages=162}}</ref>
The offerings and promotions at [[SeaWorld]] associated with the educational topics of [[marine biology]], [[Conservation biology|conservation]], and animal rescue efforts are increasing at their current locations and in plans for the upcoming [[SeaWorld Abu Dhabi|Abu Dhabi theme park]], which is likely due to activism for animal rights.<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=SeaWorld Shifts to Educational Entertainment, Adds Virtual-Reality Ride; Theme-park moves further away from controversial orca shows|last=Hufford|first=Austen|date=27 September 2016|work=The Wall Street Journal (Online)|access-date=|publisher=Dow Jones & Company Inc}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=SeaWorld writes a new chapter with first killer whale-free park|last=Lindsay|first=Rowena|date=14 December 2016|work=The Christian Science Monitor|access-date=|location=Boston, Mass.|issn=0882-7729}}</ref>
Other notable theme parks that incorporate educational elements and topics are [[Disney's Animal Kingdom]], [[Holy Land Experience]], [[Dinosaur World (theme parks)|Dinosaur World]], [[Busch Gardens]], and [[Puy du Fou]].
=== Museums and public access areas ===
Edutainment is also a growing [[paradigm]] within the [[Science museum|science center]] and [[children's museum]] community in the United States, as well as in many other locations such as the [[zoo]] or a [[botanical garden]]. Educational locations such as these are constantly looking for new and innovative ways to reach the surrounding public and get them interested in areas such as the fine arts, science, literature, and history. Additionally, [[field trip]] visits to these educational places provide participants with interactional stimulus to learn about the content offered there. Since people are used to flashy, polished entertainment venues like movie theaters and theme parks, they demand similar experiences at science centers or museums. Consequently, interactive experiences, such as games and [[mobile app]]s, are implemented in museums in order to more effectively help people learn about what they are seeing.<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=ART; TAP AND TOUR; Museums are quietly adapting to the app-happy 'selfie culture'|last=Gelt|first=Jessica|date=25 October 2015|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=|issn=0458-3035}}</ref> Museums are also embracing the ability to use storytelling to engage people, especially those who are young, in hopes to increase attendance; all the while, though, it is possible for the focus and purpose of museums to be diluted.<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=ARENA --- The Museum of The Future --- From 3-D headsets to holograms, new technologies are revolutionizing exhibits; is it entertainment or education?|last=Gamerman|first=Ellen|date=16 October 2015|work=The Wall Street Journal|access-date=|location=New York, N.Y.|edition= Eastern|issn=0099-9660}}</ref> Thus, a museum or a zoo can be seen as just another business competing for entertainment dollars from the public, rather than as an institution that serves the public welfare through education or historical preservation.<ref>{{cite book|url=|title=High Tech Heretic|last=Stoll|first=Clifford|publisher=Doubleday|year=1999|isbn=0-385-48975-7|location=|pages=485–499|doi=|id=|coauthors=|authorlink=}}</ref> [[File:Interactive exhibit at the museum of London (4905588959).jpg|link=[[:File:Interactive exhibit at the museum of London (4905588959]]).jpg|center|thumb|280x280px|An interactive exhibit at the [[Museum of London]]]]
== Effects in the classroom == {{Main|Entertainment in education}}Much research has been done in association with edutainment and its effectiveness in its various forms. Particularly, the effects of the implementation of the concept of edutainment in the classroom setting have been studied on multiple occasions. The concept of [[flipped classroom]]s, in association with edutainment, was studied by Retta Guy and Gerald Marquis (2016), in which students were assigned [[video lesson]]s and podcasts as opposed to projects prior to class; it was found that these students outperformed those in traditional classrooms, found the actual time in class to prompt more interaction, and thought the class to be more enjoyable, although there was a noticeable period of adaption.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Guy|first=Retta|last2=Marquis|first2=Gerald|date=2016|title=The Flipped Classroom: A Comparison of Student Performance Using Instructional Videos and Podcasts Versus the Lecture-Based Model of Instruction|url=|journal=Issues in Informing Science & Information Technology|volume= 13|pages= 1–13|issn=1547-5840|doi=10.28945/3461}}</ref>
In a study conducted by Ruby Lynch-Arroyo and Joyce Asing-Cashman (2016), ''[[Numbers (TV series)|Numb3rs]]'', which is an example of edutainment in the form of a television show, was integrated into the education of [[Pre-service teacher education|preservice]] mathematics teachers. The subsequent results exemplified the potential for edutainment to promote [[critical thinking]], increased engagement, and [[growth mindset]]s.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Lynch-Arroyo|first=Ruby|last2=Asing-Cashman|first2=Joyce|date=2016|title=Using Edutainment to Facilitate Mathematical Thinking and Learning: An Exploratory Study|url=http://educationforatoz.com/images/2016_Research_3.pdf|journal=Journal of Mathematics Education|volume=9|pages= 37–52|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170817203754/http://educationforatoz.com/images/2016_Research_3.pdf|archivedate=2017-08-17|df=}}</ref>
Similarly, Craig D. Cox, ''et al''. (2017) conducted a study in which a mini-series that combined educational and entertaining elements was developed and presented to pharmacy [[preceptor]]s; it was effective in increasing the confidence of the participants and was an honorable mention for the [[American Association of Colleges of Pharmacy]] Innovations in Teaching Award in 2015.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cox|first=Craig D.|last2=Cheon|first2=Jongpil|last3=Crooks|first3=Steven M.|last4=Lee|first4=Jaehoon|date=2017|title=Use of Entertainment Elements in an Online Video Mini-Series to Train Pharmacy Preceptors|url=|journal=American Journal of Pharmaceutical Education|volume= 81|issue=1|pages= 1–13|issn=0002-9459}}</ref>
A system that incorporated the concept of edutainment through the use of games has also been studied in association with [[Disability|disabled]] students by Amal Dandashi, ''et al''. (2015), and it was found that the system had a positive impact in terms of scores, coordination, communication, and memorization skills; after replaying, higher scores were often achieved as well.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dandashi|first=Amal|last2=Karkar|first2=Abdel Ghani|last3=Saad|first3=Sawsan|last4=Barhoumi|first4=Zaara|last5=Al-Jaam|first5=Jihad|last6=Saddik|first6=Abdulmotaleb El|date=2015-01-01|title=Enhancing the Cognitive and Learning Skills of Children with Intellectual Disability through Physical Activity and Edutainment Games|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1155/2015/165165|journal=International Journal of Distributed Sensor Networks|language=en|volume=11|issue=6|doi=10.1155/2015/165165|page=165165}}</ref>
As for podcasts and narration specifically, according to a study conducted by Trish L. Varao Sousa, Jonathan S. A. Carriere, and Daniel Smilek (2013) with student participants, these forms may not be particularly helpful, as their use can result in both less information actually internalized and less engagement overall when compared to other "reading encounters."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Varao Sousa|first=Trish L.|last2=Carriere|first2=Jonathan S. A.|last3=Smilek|first3=Daniel|date=2013-01-01|title=The way we encounter reading material influences how frequently we mind wander|url=http://journal.frontiersin.org/article/10.3389/fpsyg.2013.00892/abstract|journal=Frontiers in Psychology|language=English|volume=4|page=892|doi=10.3389/fpsyg.2013.00892|issn=1664-1078|pmid=24348444|pmc=3842750|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160409030804/http://journal.frontiersin.org/article/10.3389/fpsyg.2013.00892/abstract|archivedate=2016-04-09|df=}}</ref>
== Criticism == Debate regarding the value of educational entertainment and its implementation has been had for decades.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2006/07/thats-edutainment/305126/|title=That's Edutainment|last=Rozen|first=Joel|work=The Atlantic|access-date=2017-04-13|language=en-US|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160323160117/http://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2006/07/thats-edutainment/305126/|archivedate=2016-03-23|df=}}</ref> The negative feedback received by Walt Disney for his ''[[True-Life Adventures]]'' series represents the views of some skeptics of the concept of edutainment. For example, the use of music along with the footage of animals, such as the circumstance in which "The courtship of tarantulas was set to a tango, while the movements of two scorpions were showcased with square dance music in the background" was criticized at the time; the purpose of the music was to enhance the footage, but some people took issue with this humanization. Additionally, without approval, some of the film crew of ''[[White Wilderness (film)|White Wilderness]]'' prompted unnatural behavior in lemmings that would be filmed, which then generated a negative response.<ref name=":10">{{Cite news|url=http://waltdisney.org/blog/walt-and-true-life-adventures|title=Walt and the True-Life Adventures|last=admin|date=2012-02-09|work=The Walt Disney Family Museum|access-date=2017-04-17|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170419053222/http://waltdisney.org/blog/walt-and-true-life-adventures|archivedate=2017-04-19|df=}}</ref>
''[[Sesame Street]]'', a television show that demonstrates the concept of edutainment, has also specifically been subject to criticism. For instance, in an article published in ''[[The Atlantic]]'' in May 1971, [[John Holt (educator)|John Holt]] criticizes the promotion of "Right Answers" in the television show without actual action being taken by the children, and also argues that it is nonsensical and perplexing to have adults convey to children that everything that is to be discovered is logical and easy to understand.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/1971/05/big-bird-meet-dick-and-jane/305125/|title=Big Bird, Meet Dick and Jane|last=Holt|first=John|date=May 1971|work=The Atlantic|access-date=2017-04-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160523172022/http://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/1971/05/big-bird-meet-dick-and-jane/305125/|archive-date=2016-05-23|dead-url=no|language=en-US|df=}}</ref>
The argument that the concept of edutainment hurts the actual value of education has been prevalent as well. The book entitled ''[[Amusing Ourselves to Death]]'' by theorist [[Neil Postman]] demonstrates this notion, as it is claimed that areas of study have been “transformed into congenial adjuncts of show business.”<ref>Neil., Postman, (1986-01-01). {{oclc|14271773}} ''Amusing ourselves to death : public discourse in the age of show business''. Heinemann. {{ISBN|978-0-434-59300-2}} {{oclc|14271773}}. As cited in Beato, Greg (2015-03-19). [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/20/education/turning-to-education-for-fun.html "Turning to Education for Fun"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170105130008/http://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/20/education/turning-to-education-for-fun.html |date=2017-01-05 }}. ''The New York Times''. [[International Standard Serial Number|ISSN]] [https://www.worldcat.org/issn/0362-4331 0362-4331] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180416041928/http://www.worldcat.org/issn/0362-4331 |date=2018-04-16 }}. Retrieved 2017-04-12.</ref> Museum professionals especially have faced this dilemma, as in study conducted by Pierre Balloffet, François H. Courvoisier, and Joëlle Lagier (2014), museum professionals did not have severe negative opinions of the incorporation of educational entertainment, but individuals nevertheless had varying viewpoints on "the appropriateness or potential risks of edutainment."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Balloffet|first=Pierre|last2=Courvoisier|first2=François H.|last3=Lagier|first3=Joelle|date=2014|title=From Museum to Amusement Park: The Opportunities and Risks of Edutainment|url=|journal=International Journal of Arts Management|volume=16 |issue=2|pages=}}</ref>
== See also == {{div col|colwidth=22em}} *[[After school special]] *[[Drama#Tool for education|Drama as a tool for education]] *[[Educational video game]] *[[:Category:Educational websites|Educational websites]] *[[Educational toy]] *[[Entertainment-Education]] *[[Games and learning]] *[[Infotainment]] *[[Educational software]] *[[Kami (Takalani Sesame)]] *[[Politainment]] *[[Public service announcement]] *[[Serious game]] *[[Social Impact Entertainment]] *[[Telenovelas]] *[[Traffic School by Improv]] {{div col end}}

revision.comment: /* Botanical gardens, zoos, and aquariums */ Fixed typo
revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:''Ex situ'' conservation}} '''''Ex situ'' conservation''' literally means, "off-site [[conservation movement|conservation]]". It is the process of protecting an endangered species, variety or [[breed]], of plant or animal outside its natural habitat; for example, by removing part of the population from a threatened habitat and placing it in a new location, which may be a wild area or within the care of humans.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://portals.iucn.org/library/sites/library/files/documents/2014-064.pdf|title=IUCN Species Survival Commission Guidelines on the Use of Ex situ Management for Species Conservation|date=2014|website=|publisher=IUCN|access-date=27 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cbd.int/doc/legal/cbd-en.pdf|title=Convention on Biological Diversity|date=1992|website=|publisher=United Nations|access-date=27 May 2016}}</ref> The degree to which humans control or modify the natural dynamics of the managed population varies widely, and this may include alteration of living environments, reproductive patterns, access to resources, and protection from predation and mortality. ''Ex situ'' management can occur within or outside a species' natural geographic range. Individuals maintained ''ex situ'' exist outside an [[Niche (ecology)|ecological niche]]. This means that they are not under the same selection pressures as wild populations, and they may undergo [[Selective breeding|artificial selection]] if maintained ''ex situ'' for multiple generations.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.cabi.org/bookshop/book/9780851995229|title=Managing plant genetic diversity|last=Ramanatha Rao|first=V.|last2=Brown|first2=A. H. D.|last3=Jackson|first3=M.|publisher=CABI|year=2001|isbn=|location=|pages=89}}</ref>
[[Crop diversity|Agricultural biodiversity]] is also conserved in ''ex situ'' collections. This is primarily in the form of [[gene bank]]s where samples are stored in order to conserve the genetic resources of major crop plants and their [[Crop wild relatives|wild relatives]].
== Facilities ==
===Botanical gardens, zoos, and aquariums === [[Botanical garden]]s, and [[zoo]]s are the most conventional methods of Ex-situ conservation. Also in ex- situ conservation, all of which house whole, protected specimens for breeding and reintroduction into the wild when necessary and possible. These facilities provide not only housing and care for specimens of endangered species, but also have an educational value. They inform the public of the threatened status of endangered species and of those factors which cause the threat, with the hope of creating public interest in stopping and reversing those factors which jeopardize a species' survival in the first place. They are the most publicly visited ex situ conservation sites, with the WZCS (World Zoo Conservation Strategy) estimating that the 1100 organized zoos in the world receive more than 600 million visitors annually. Globally there is an estimated total of 2,107 aquaria and zoos in 125 countries. Additionally many private collectors or other not-for-profit groups hold animals and they engage in conservation or reintroduction efforts.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Ex situ plant conservation: supporting species survival in the wild|last=Guerrant|first=Edward|last2=Havens|first2=Kayri|last3=Maunder|first3=Mike|publisher=Island Press|year=2004|isbn=|location=|pages=91}}</ref> Similarly there are approximately 2,000 botanical gardens in 148 counties cultivating or storing an estimated 80,000 [[Taxon|taxa]] of plants.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Ex situ plant conservation: supporting species survival in the wild|last=Guerrant|first=Edward|last2=Havens|first2=Karyi|last3=Maunder|first3=MIke|publisher=Island Press|year=2004|isbn=|location=|pages=10–11}}</ref>
== Techniques for plants ==
=== Cryopreservation === The storage of seeds, pollen, tissue, or embryos in liquid nitrogen. This method can be used for virtually indefinite storage of material without deterioration over a much greater time-period relative to all other methods of ''ex situ'' conservation. Cryopreservation is also used for the conservation of livestock genetics through [[Cryoconservation of animal genetic resources]]. Technical limitations prevent the cryopreservation of many species, but [[cryobiology]] is a field of active research, and many studies concerning plants are underway.
=== Seed banking === The storage of seeds in a temperature and moisture controlled environment. This technique is used for taxa with orthodox seeds that tolerate [[desiccation]]. Seed bank facilities vary from sealed boxes to climate controlled walk-in freezers or vaults. Taxa with recalcitrant seeds that do not tolerate desiccation are typically not held in seed banks for extended periods of time.
=== Tissue culture (storage and propagation) === Somatic tissue can be stored ''[[in vitro]]'' for short periods of time. This is done in a light and temperature controlled environment that regulates the growth of cells. As a e''x situ'' conservation technique tissue culture is primary used for clonal propagation of vegetative tissue or immature seeds. This allows for the proliferation of clonal plants from a relatively small amount of parent tissue.
=== Field gene banking === An extensive open-air planting used maintain [[genetic diversity]] of wild, agricultural, or forestry species. Typically species that are either difficult or impossible to conserve in seed banks are conserved in field gene banks. Field gene banks may also be used grow and select progeny of species stored by other ''ex situ'' techniques.
=== Cultivation collections === Plants under [[Horticulture|horticultural]] care in a constructed landscape, typically a botanic garden or arboreta. This technique is similar to a field gene bank in that plants are maintained in the ambient environment, but the collections are typically not as genetically diverse or extensive. These collections are susceptible to hybridization, artificial selection, genetic drift, and disease transmission. Species that cannot be conserved by other ''ex situ'' techniques are often included in cultivated collections.
=== Inter situ === Plants are under horticulture care, but the environment is managed to near natural conditions. This occurs with either restored or semi-natural environments. This technique is primarily used for taxa that are rare or in areas where habitat has been severely degraded.
== Techniques for animals == [[Image:Liquid nitrogen tank.JPG|thumb|150px|A tank of [[liquid nitrogen]], used to supply a cryogenic freezer (for storing laboratory samples at a temperature of about −150 °C).]]
Endangered animal species and breeds are preserved using similar techniques.<ref>FAO. 2012. [http://www.fao.org/docrep/016/i3017e/i3017e00.htm Cryoconservation of animal genetic resources. FAO Animal Production and Health Guidelines.] No. 12. Rome.</ref> Animal species can be preserved in [[genebank]]s, which consist of [[cryogenic]] facilities used to store living [[Spermatozoon|sperm]], [[Ovum|eggs]], or [[embryo]]s. For example, the Zoological Society of San Diego has established a "[[frozen zoo]]" to store such samples using [[cryopreservation]] techniques from more than 355 species, including mammals, reptiles, and birds.
A potential technique for aiding in reproduction of endangered species is [[interspecific pregnancy]], implanting embryos of an endangered species into the womb of a female of a related species, carrying it to term.<ref name=NiasariNaslaji2009>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1071/RD08140 | last1 = Niasari-Naslaji | first1 = A. | last2 = Nikjou | first2 = D. | last3 = Skidmore | first3 = J. A. | last4 = Moghiseh | first4 = A. | last5 = Mostafaey | first5 = M. | last6 = Razavi | first6 = K. | last7 = Moosavi-Movahedi | first7 = A. A. | title = Interspecies embryo transfer in camelids: the birth of the first Bactrian camel calves (Camelus bactrianus) from dromedary camels (Camelus dromedarius) | journal = Reproduction, fertility, and development | volume = 21 | issue = 2 | pages = 333–337 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19210924 }}</ref> It has been carried out for the [[Spanish ibex]].<ref name=FernandezArias1999>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S0093-691X(99)00086-2 |url=http://media.longnow.org/files/2/REVIVE/THER1999%20Interspec.%20embr.%20transfer%20S.Ibex%20Dom.goat.pdf | last1 = Fernández-Arias | first1 = A. | last2 = Alabart | first2 = J. L. | last3 = Folch | first3 = J. | last4 = Beckers | first4 = J. F. | title = Interspecies pregnancy of Spanish ibex (''Capra pyrenaica'') fetus in domestic goat (''Capra hircus'') recipients induces abnormally high plasmatic levels of pregnancy-associated glycoprotein | journal = Theriogenology | volume = 51 | issue = 8 | pages = 1419–1430 | year = 1999 | pmid = 10729070 }}</ref>
== Genetic management of captive populations == Captive populations are subject to problems such as [[inbreeding depression]], loss of [[genetic diversity]] and adaptations to captivity. It is important to manage captive populations in a way that minimizes these issues so that the individuals to be introduced will resemble the original founders as closely as possible, which will increase the chances of successful [[Species reintroduction|reintroductions]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Wild Mammals in Captivity: Principles and Techniques for Zoo Management|last=Kleiman|first=Devra|last2=Thompson|first2=Katerina|last3=Baer|first3=Charlotte|publisher=University of Chicago Press|year=2010|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> During the initial growth phase, the population size is rapidly expanded until a target population size is reached.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Introduction to Conservation Genetics|last=Frankham|first=Dick|last2=Ballou|first2=Jon|last3=Briscoe|first3=David|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2011|isbn=978-0-521-70271-3|location=United Kingdom|pages=430–471}}</ref> The target population size is the number of individuals that are required to maintain appropriate levels of genetic diversity, which is generally considered to by 90% of the current genetic diversity after 100 years.<ref name=":0" /> The number of individuals required to meet this goal varies based on potential growth rate, effective size, current genetic diversity, and generation time.<ref name=":1" /> Once the target population size is reached, the focus shifts to maintaining the population and avoiding genetic issues within the captive population.<ref name=":0" />
=== Minimizing mean kinship === Managing populations based on minimizing mean kinship values is often an effective way to increase genetic diversity and to avoid inbreeding within captive populations.<ref name=":0" /> Kinship is the probability that two alleles will be [[Identity by descent|identical by descent]] when one allele is taken randomly from each mating individual. The mean kinship value is the average kinship value between a given individual and every other member of the population. Mean kinship values can help determine which individuals should be mated. In choosing individuals for breeding, it is important to choose individuals with the lowest mean kinship values because these individuals are least related to the rest of the population and have the least common alleles.<ref name=":0" /> This ensures that rarer [[allele]]s are passed on, which helps to increase genetic diversity. It is also important to avoid mating two individuals with very different mean kinship values because such pairings propagate both the rare alleles that are present in the individual with the low mean kinship value as well as the common alleles that are present in the individual with the high mean kinship value.<ref name=":0" /> This genetic management technique requires that ancestry is known, so in circumstances where ancestry is unknown, it might be necessary to use molecular genetics such as [[microsatellite]] data to help resolve unknowns.<ref name=":1" />
=== Avoiding loss of genetic diversity === Genetic diversity is often lost within captive populations due to the [[founder effect]] and subsequent small population sizes.<ref name=":0" /> Minimizing the loss of genetic diversity within the captive population is an important component of ''ex situ'' conservation and is critical for successful reintroductions and the long term success of the species, since more diverse populations have higher [[Adaptation|adaptive]] potential.<ref name=":1" /> The loss of genetic diversity due to the founder effect can be minimized by ensuring that the founder population is large enough and genetically representative of the wild population.<ref name=":0" /> This is often difficult because removing large numbers of individuals from the wild populations may further reduce the genetic diversity of a species that is already of conservation concern. Maximizing the captive population size and the [[effective population size]] can decrease the loss of genetic diversity by minimizing the random loss of alleles due to [[genetic drift]] .<ref name=":0" /> Minimizing the number of generations in captivity is another effective method for reducing the loss of genetic diversity in captive populations.<ref name=":0" />
=== Avoiding adaptations to captivity === [[Natural selection|Selection]] favors different traits in captive populations than it does in wild populations, so this may result in adaptations that are beneficial in captivity but are deleterious in the wild.<ref name=":0" /> This reduces the success of re-introductions, so it is important to manage captive populations in order to reduce adaptations to captivity. Adaptations to captivity can be reduced by minimizing the number of generations in captivity and by maximizing the number of migrants from wild populations.<ref name=":0" /> Minimizing selection on captive populations by creating an environment that is similar to their natural environment is another method of reducing adaptations to captivity, but it is important to find a balance between an environment that minimizes adaptation to captivity and an environment that permits adequate reproduction.<ref name=":0" /> Adaptations to captivity can also be reduced by managing the captive population as a series of population fragments. In this management strategy, the captive population is split into several sub-populations or fragments which are maintained separately. Smaller populations have lower adaptive potentials, so the population fragments are less likely to accumulate adaptations associated with captivity. The fragments are maintained separately until [[inbreeding]] becomes a concern. Immigrants are then exchanged between the fragments to reduce inbreeding, and then the fragments are managed separately again.<ref name=":0" />
=== Managing genetic disorders === [[Genetic disorder]]s are often an issue within captive populations due to the fact that the populations are usually established from a small number of founders.<ref name=":0" /> In large, [[Outcrossing|outbreeding]] populations, the frequencies of most deleterious alleles are relatively low, but when a population undergoes a bottleneck during the founding of a captive population, previously rare alleles may survive and increase in number.<ref name=":1" /> Further inbreeding within the captive population may also increase the likelihood that deleterious alleles will be expressed due to increasing [[Zygosity|homozygosity]] within the population.<ref name=":1" /> The high occurrence of genetic disorders within a captive population can threaten both the survival of the captive population and its eventual reintroduction back into the wild.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Laikre|first=Linda|date=1999|title=Hereditary Defects and Conservation Genetic Management of Captive Populations|url=|journal=Zoo Biology|doi=10.1002/(sici)1098-2361(1999)18:2<81::aid-zoo1>3.0.co;2-2}}</ref> If the genetic disorder is [[Dominance (genetics)|dominant]], it may be possible to eliminate the disease completely in a single generation by avoiding breeding of the affected individuals.<ref name=":0" /> However, if the genetic disorder is [[Recessive allele|recessive]], it may not be possible to completely eliminate the allele due to its presence in unaffected [[Zygosity|heterozygotes]].<ref name=":0" /> In this case, the best option is to attempt to minimize the frequency of the allele by selectively choosing mating pairs. In the process of eliminating genetic disorders, it is important to consider that when certain individuals are prevented from breeding, alleles and therefore genetic diversity are removed from the population; if these alleles aren't present in other individuals, they may be lost completely.<ref name=":2" /> Preventing certain individuals from the breeding also reduces the effective population size, which is associated with problems such as the loss of genetic diversity and increased inbreeding.<ref name=":0" />
== Examples == [[Showy Indian clover]], ''Trifolium amoenum'', is an example of a species that was thought to be extinct, but was rediscovered in 1993<ref>Connors, P. G. (1994) [http://docubase.berkeley.edu/cgi-bin/pl_dochome?query_src=pl_search&collection=Fremontia&id=158 ''Rediscovery of showy Indian clover'']. Fremontia 22: 3–7</ref> in the form of a single plant at a site in western [[Sonoma County]].<ref>U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Arcata Division, 1655 Heindon Road, Arcata, Ca.</ref> Seeds were harvested and currently grown in ex situ facilities.
The [[Wollemi pine]] is another example of a plant that is being preserved via ''ex situ'' conservation, as they are being grown in nurseries to be sold to the general public.
== Drawbacks == ''Ex situ'' conservation, while helpful in humankind's efforts to sustain and protect our environment, is rarely enough to save a species from extinction. It is to be used as a last resort, or as a supplement to [[in situ conservation]] because it cannot recreate the habitat as a whole: the entire [[genetic variation]] of a species, its [[symbiosis|symbiotic]] counterparts, or those elements which, over time, might help a species adapt to its changing surroundings. Instead, ''ex situ'' conservation removes the species from its natural ecological contexts, preserving it under semi-isolated conditions whereby natural evolution and adaptation processes are either temporarily halted or altered by introducing the specimen to an unnatural habitat. In the case of [[cryogenic]] storage methods, the preserved specimen's adaptation processes are (quite literally) frozen altogether. The downside to this is that, when re-released, the species may lack the genetic adaptations and mutations which would allow it to thrive in its ever-changing natural habitat.
Furthermore, ''ex situ'' conservation techniques are often costly, with cryogenic storage being economically infeasible in most cases since species stored in this manner cannot provide a profit but instead slowly drain the financial resources of the government or organization determined to operate them. [[Seedbank]]s are ineffective for certain plant [[genus|genera]] with recalcitrant seeds that do not remain fertile for long periods of time. Diseases and pests foreign to the species, to which the species has no natural defense, may also cripple crops of protected plants in ''ex situ'' plantations and in animals living in ''ex situ'' breeding grounds. These factors, combined with the specific environmental needs of many species, some of which are nearly impossible to recreate by man, make ''ex situ'' conservation impossible for a great number of the world's endangered flora and fauna.

revision.text:
'''Geragogy''' is a theory which argues that [[Geriatrics|older adults]] are sufficiently different that they warrant a separate [[educational theory]]. The term "eldergogy" has also been used.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Yeo|first=Gwen|date=1982|title='Eldergogy': A special approach to education for elders|url=|journal=Lifelong Learning: The Adult Years|issue=5(5)|pages=4-7|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> Some critics have noted that "one should not expect from geragogy some comprehensive educational theory for older adult learners, but only an awareness of and sensitivity towards gerontological issues".<ref>{{Cite book|title=Lifelong Learning in Later Life: a handbook on older adult learning|last=Findsen|first=Brian|last2=Formosa|first2=Marvin|publisher=Sense Publishers|year=2011|isbn=978-94-6091-649-6|location=Dordrecht|pages=105}}</ref>
Key distinctions between traditional [[pedagogy]] and geragogy include offering "opportunities for older adult learners to set the curriculum themselves and to learn through activities of personal relevance"<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wright|first=Pat|date=2016|title=Helping older people conquer digital tablets.|url=http://gerontechnology.info/index.php/journal/article/view/gt.2016.14.2.005.00|journal=Gerontechnology|issue=14(2)|pages=78-88|doi=10.4017/gt.2016.14.2.005.00|pmid=|access-date=23 March 2016}}</ref> as well as recognition of age-related issues which may affect learning, such as reduced [[Perception|sensory perception]], limited motor capabilities and changes in cognitive processes, especially [[memory]].
Collaborative [[peer learning]], as employed in the [[University of the Third Age]], is a common element within geragogic settings.
== Principles of geragogy<ref>{{Cite book|title=Geragogy: A theory for teaching the elderly|last=John|first=Martha T.|publisher=The Haworth Press|year=1988|isbn=9780866567145|location=Binghampton, NY|pages=}}</ref> ==
*[[File:Vuxenutbildning.jpg|thumb|Older people in a peer learning setting]]Learning should aim to provide skills and resources which maintain personal independence. Useful, practical outcomes must therefore be highlighted before a course of study begins, and any assigned tasks must have meaning for older adults. Enjoyment, curiosity, seeking information and desiring communication are typical routes into learning. * Variety in teaching methods is required, rather than reliance on lengthy verbal presentations. A flexible, interdisciplinary approach which responds to the needs of the learners present is vital. * Tutors should strive to maintain a clear focus on the topic, limiting the number of ideas presented. Irrelevant or overly distracting concepts should be avoided. * In place of discipline or rote-learning, tutors should stimulate engagement with warmth, positive comments, approval and encouragement. * Learners may take longer to complete tasks and assignments than younger people. They may also wish to return repeatedly to a task until they feel comfortable. Examples should be reinforced regularly and often, using differing contexts in order to give as many opportunities as possible for learners to grasp a concept. * The past experiences of learners can be useful in grounding their understanding. Tutors should seek to review specific skills which allow each learner to be creative in their own way, building on their personal life experience. It is also important to review information that may have been learned in the past (such as at school) but has not been used for some time.
==References== <references />
==Further reading== *Pearson, M. (2011). "Gerogogy in patient education - revisited". ''The Oklahoma Nurse'' 56(2): 12-17. *Pearson, M. (1986). "Gerogogy in patient education". ''Home Healthcare Nurse'' 14(8): 631-636. *Battersby, D. (1987). "From andragogy to geragogy". ''Journal of Educational Gerontology'' 2(1): 4-10. *Formosa, M. (2002). "Critical gerogogy: Developing practical possibilities for critical educational gerontology". ''Education and Ageing'' 17(3): 73-86. *John, M.T. (1983). ''Teaching and loving the elderly''. Springfield, IL: Charles C. Thomas. *Lebel, J. (1978). "Beyond Andragogy to geragogy". ''Lifelong learning: The adult years'' 1(9): 16-8.
[[Category:Pedagogy]] [[Category:Educational stages]] [[Category:Adult education]]

'''H. Thomas Johnson''' (born 1938) is an [[Americans|American]] [[History of accounting|accounting historian]], and Professor of [[Business Administration]] at [[Portland State University]], known for his work on the [[history of accounting]] and accounting thought <ref>[[Kaplan, Robert S.]] "[http://kczx.gzhu.edu.cn/course_center/files_upload/template/6C473DC0-9248-4A50-A2B2-04741AAD2F02/COLUMN_16/file3/09.pdf The evolution of management accounting] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141222130258/http://kczx.gzhu.edu.cn/course_center/files_upload/template/6C473DC0-9248-4A50-A2B2-04741AAD2F02/COLUMN_16/file3/09.pdf |date=2014-12-22 }}," ''The Accounting Review,'' Vol 14, No 3. July 1986.</ref><ref>[[Richard Vangermeersch]]. "[https://books.google.nl/books?id=DmnMAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA354 Johnson, H. Thomas, 1938-]" in: [[Michael Chatfield]], Richard Vangermeersch, ''The History of Accounting (RLE Accounting): An International Encyclopedia.'' 2014. p. 354-355</ref>
== Life and work == Johnson obtained his BA in economics from [[Harvard University]] and his MBA in accounting from [[Rutgers University]]. For his graduate studies he moved to the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]], where he obtained a PhD in economic history. He went on to earn a [[Certified Public Accountant]] license.<ref name="PDX 2015">[http://www.pdx.edu/sba/h-thomas-johnson H. Thomas Johnson profile] at Portland State University. Accessed 10.02.2015</ref>
After graduation Johnson started as accountant at [[Arthur Andersen]]. In the early 1970s he started his academic career at the University of Western Ontario as Assistant Professor of Economics, and by 1975 was Associate Professor of Economics. In 1980 he was appointed Professor of Accounting at the Western Washington University. In 1988 he move to the [[Portland State University]], where he was appointed Professor of Business Administration. At the Bainbridge Graduate Institute in Washington he is also appointed Distinguished Consulting Professor of Sustainable Business.
A 2003 survey by Harvard Business School Press placed him among the 200 leading management thinkers living today. The American Society for Quality awarded him the Deming Medal, and in 2007 he received a distinguished lifetime achievement award from the American Accounting Association.<ref name="PDX 2015"/>
Johnson's research interests are in the field of "the intersection of systems thinking, modern physics, and sustainable operations management. He is exploring the application of natural living system principles to the design of ecologically-focused local business operations that emulate and extend the scope of the Toyota Production System."<ref name="PDX 2015"/>
==Selected publications== * Johnson, H. Thomas. ''Relevance lost: the rise and fall of management accounting.'' Harvard Business Press, 1991. * Johnson, H. Thomas. ''Relevance regained.'' Simon and Schuster, 2002.<ref>{{cite book|author=H. Thomas Johnson|title=Relevance Regained|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Vs3sr_AN_pQC|date=2002|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=978-1-4391-0589-4}}</ref>
Articles, a selection: * Johnson, H. Thomas, and [[Robert S. Kaplan]]. "The rise and fall of management accounting." ''Engineering Management Review,'' IEEE 15.3 (1987): 36-44. * Johnson, H. Thomas. "It’s time to stop overselling activity-based concepts." ''Management Accounting'' 74.3 (1992): 26-35.
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== External links == * [http://www.pdx.edu/sba/h-thomas-johnson H. Thomas Johnson] profile at Portland State University
